channel.title: Raspberry Pi - $25 PC
channel.description:
http://www.raspberrypi.org/ ------- Taken from official website ------------------------
The Raspberry Pi Foundation is a UK registered charity (Registration Number 1129409) which exists to promote the study of computer science and related topics, especially at school level, and to put the fun back into learning computing.
We plan to develop, manufacture and distribute an ultra-low-cost computer, for use in teaching computer programming to children. We expect this computer to have many other applications both in the developed and the developing world.
Our first product is about the size of a USB key, and is designed to plug into a TV or be combined with a touch screen for a low cost tablet. The expected price is $25 for a fully-configured system.
Provisional specification
700MHz ARM11 256MB of SDRAM OpenGL ES 2.0 1080p30 H.264 high-profile decode Composite and HDMI video output USB 2.0 SD/MMC/SDIO memory card slot General-purpose I/O Open software (Ubuntu, Iceweasel, KOffice, Python) Frequently asked questions
[b]When will the device be available to purchase? [/b] We anticipate the device will be available to the general public later in 2011.
[b]How do I connect a mouse and keyboard?[/b] Mice, keyboards, network adapters and external storage connect via a USB HUB. [b] What are the power requirements?[/b]
The device is powered by an external AC adapter, and consumes a little under 1W at full load. [b]Will there be a buy-one-give-one program? [/b] Yes. We plan to implement a program of this sort. [img]http://www.raspberrypi.org/ubuntu.jpg[/img] Raspberry Pi device running Ubuntu 9.04 [img]http://www.raspberrypi.org/pcb.jpg[/img] Raspberry Pi device with attached 12MPixel camera module ---------------------------------------- Discuss. I'm getting one probably

item.title: Raspberry Pi - $25 PC
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:9, topic:399338”]old news.

Anyway, just keep it in a box - make your own casing!

I still push on that the idea of this being a “cheap computer for everyone” is a bit misleading and stupid. Yes the actual base unit costs $25/£15, but the real flaw is that you must have a HDMI enabled television to use this. If you add up the cost of even a really cheap television with a HDMI port plus the £15 for the unit it comes out at around the same price as a cheap low-end netbook.

I wonder how well that cpu pulls out, I mean ARM11 should be big advantage to similarly clocked cpu’s in most smartphones![/quote]
Nobody said this was a powerful computer or anything of the sorts. Also, my PC Monitor has an HDMI port by itself. Got it for around $75 (used) so it really shouldn’t be that big of a deal.

Read full topic

item.title: Raspberry Pi - $25 PC

@Java_Is_My_Bitch2 wrote:

Of course it’s possible, but 25$? Daaammn, most good keyboards cost more than that lolol. What if in the future you’de get tiny computers in your happymeals, haha.

item.title: Raspberry Pi - $25 PC
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

old news.

Anyway, just keep it in a box - make your own casing!

I still push on that the idea of this being a “cheap computer for everyone” is a bit misleading and stupid. Yes the actual base unit costs $25/£15, but the real flaw is that you must have a HDMI enabled television to use this. If you add up the cost of even a really cheap television with a HDMI port plus the £15 for the unit it comes out at around the same price as a cheap low-end netbook.

I wonder how well that cpu pulls out, I mean ARM11 should be big advantage to similarly clocked cpu’s in most smartphones!

Read full topic

@Slave_Scyth wrote:

[quote=“rip4d, post:5, topic:399338”]It probably (hopefully) will have some kind of casing when it is released. I mean, I don’t think (hope) anyone would really sell something like that as is.[/quote]This. Considering they’re still testing it, and don’t seem to be too massive of a company, they probably are just messing with like an Arduino sort of deal to do all of this. Looks amazing, though.

item.title: Raspberry Pi - $25 PC
item.dc:creator: @rip4d rip4d
item.description:
@rip4d wrote:

Aw, its so cute!

In all seriousness though, I may get one as well. Considering it can fit in my pocket and you can use SD cards with it for extra storage/RAM (not sure if Linux supports that function), it could become more functional than most people may anticipate.

Hell, if I could get a solar adapter for that thing, I could render fractals on the go. It would be great

Read full topic

item.title: Raspberry Pi - $25 PC
item.dc:creator: @Muroth Muroth
item.description:
@Muroth wrote:

Raspberry Pi

Raspberry Pi - Teach, Learn, and Make with Raspberry Pi

The Raspberry Pi is a tiny and affordable computer that you can use to learn programming through fun, practical projects. Join the global Raspberry Pi Community.


------- Taken from official website ------------------------

The Raspberry Pi Foundation is a UK registered charity (Registration Number 1129409) which exists to promote the study of computer science and related topics, especially at school level, and to put the fun back into learning computing.

We plan to develop, manufacture and distribute an ultra-low-cost computer, for use in teaching computer programming to children. We expect this computer to have many other applications both in the developed and the developing world.

Our first product is about the size of a USB key, and is designed to plug into a TV or be combined with a touch screen for a low cost tablet. The expected price is $25 for a fully-configured system.

Provisional specification

700MHz ARM11
256MB of SDRAM
OpenGL ES 2.0
1080p30 H.264 high-profile decode
Composite and HDMI video output
USB 2.0
SD/MMC/SDIO memory card slot
General-purpose I/O
Open software (Ubuntu, Iceweasel, KOffice, Python)
Frequently asked questions

When will the device be available to purchase?

We anticipate the device will be available to the general public later in 2011.

How do I connect a mouse and keyboard?
Mice, keyboards, network adapters and external storage connect via a USB HUB.

What are the power requirements?

The device is powered by an external AC adapter, and consumes a little under 1W at full load.
Will there be a buy-one-give-one program?

Yes. We plan to implement a program of this sort.

Raspberry Pi device running Ubuntu 9.04

Raspberry Pi device with attached 12MPixel camera module

Discuss. I’m getting one probably
